question: When considering air: 1- Air has mass 2- Air is not compressible 3-Air is able to flow or change its shape when subject to even small pressures 4-The viscosity of air is very high 5-Moving air has kinetic energy. The correct combination of all true statements is:
explanation:
• Air has mass – Correct (Air is made up of molecules, so it has mass).
  • Air is not compressible – Incorrect (Air is a gas and is highly compressible).
  • Air can flow or change its shape under small pressures – Correct (Air behaves as a fluid and adapts to pressure changes).
  • The viscosity of air is very high – Incorrect (Air has low viscosity compared to liquids).
  • Moving air has kinetic energy – Correct (Anything in motion has kinetic energy, including air).
subject: Technical

question: Why do the lower layers contain the greater proportion of the whole mass of the atmosphere:

choices.choice: Because of greater levels of humidity at low altitude
Because air has very little mass

explanation:
• Air is compressible, meaning its density increases under pressure.
  • The weight of the atmosphere compresses the air at lower altitudes, making it denser and containing a greater proportion of the atmosphere’s mass.
  • Higher altitudes have lower pressure, causing air to expand and become less dense.
subject: Technical

question: With increasing altitude, up to about 40,000 ft, the characteristics of air change: 1 – Temperature decreases continuously with altitude 2 – Pressure falls steadily to an altitude of about 36,000 ft, where it then remains constant 3 – Density decreases steadily with increasing altitude 4 – Pressure falls steadily with increasing altitude The combination of true statements is:
explanation:
• Temperature decreases with altitude only up to the tropopause (~36,000 ft), after which it remains nearly constant in the lower stratosphere. Hence, statement 1 is incorrect.
  • Pressure decreases steadily with altitude; it does not remain constant at 36,000 ft. Thus, statement 2 is incorrect.
  • Density decreases steadily with increasing altitude due to lower pressure and temperature, making statement 3 correct.
  • Pressure continuously falls as altitude increases, making statement 4 correct.
subject: Technical

question: When considering static pressure: 1-In aviation, static pressure can be measured in hectopascal=s 2-The SI units for static pressure is N/m² 3-Static pressure is the product of the mass of air pressing down on the air beneath 4-Referred to as static pressure because of the air’s stationary or static presence 5-The lower the altitude, the greater the static pressure. The correct statements are:
explanation:
Static Pressure
The unit for static pressure is N/m², the symbol is lower case ‘p’.
• Static pressure is the result of the weight of the atmosphere pressing down on the air beneath.
• Static pressure will exert the same force per square metre on all surfaces of an aeroplane. The lower the altitude, the greater the force per square metre.
• It is called static pressure because of the air’s stationary or static presence.• An aircraft always has static pressure acting upon it.

Newtons per square metre is the SI unit for pressure. 1 N/m² is called a pascal and is quite a small unit. In aviation, the hectopascal (hPa) is used. (‘hecto’ means 100 and 1 hectopascal is the same as 1 millibar).
subject: Technical

question: When considering air density: 1-Density is measured in millibar =s 2-Density increases with increasing altitude 3-If temperature increases the density will increase 4-As altitude increases, density will decrease 5-Temperature decreases with increasing altitude, this will cause air density to increase. The combination of correct statement is:
explanation:
• Density is measured in millibars – ❌ Incorrect (Density is measured in kg/m³, not in millibars, which is a unit of pressure).
  • Density increases with increasing altitude – ❌ Incorrect (Density decreases with altitude due to lower pressure).
  • If temperature increases, the density will increase – ❌ Incorrect (Higher temperature causes air to expand, decreasing density).
  • As altitude increases, density will decrease – ✅ Correct (Due to lower pressure at higher altitudes).
  • Temperature decreases with increasing altitude, this will cause air density to increase – ❌ Incorrect (Though temperature decreases with altitude, the dominant effect is lower pressure, leading to lower density).
subject: Technical

question: Air density is:

choices.choice: Proportional to temperature and inversely proportional to pressure
Independent of both temperature and pressure
Dependent only on decreasing pressure with increasing altitude.

explanation:
• Air density (ρ) is defined as mass per unit volume (kg/m³).
  • It is inversely proportional to temperature (higher temperature → lower density).
  • It is directly proportional to pressure (higher pressure → higher density).
  • It is not independent of temperature and pressure, and it is not only dependent on pressure, as temperature also affects it.
subject: Technical

question: When considering the ICAO International Standard Atmosphere and comparing it with the actual atmosphere, which of the following statements is correct: 1-Temperature , pressure and density are constantly changing in any given layer of the actual atmosphere. 2-A requirement exists for a hypothetical ‘standard’ atmosphere. 3-The values given in the International Standard Atmosphere exist at a the same altitudes in the actual atmosphere. 4-The International Standard Atmosphere was designed for the calibration of pressure instruments and the comparison of aircraft performance calculations
explanation:
1, 2, and 4

Explanation:

  1. True – In the actual atmosphere, temperature, pressure, and density vary constantly due to weather, altitude, and location.
  2. True – A hypothetical “standard” atmosphere is required for uniform calculations and calibrations.
  3. False – The values in the ICAO Standard Atmosphere do not necessarily exist at the same altitudes in the real atmosphere, as actual conditions vary.
  4. True – The ISA is used for calibrating pressure instruments and for aircraft performance comparisons under standard conditions.
subject: Technical

question: When considering the ICAO International Standard Atmosphere, which of the following statements is correct: 1-The temperature lapse rate is assumed to be uniform at 2°C per 1,000 ft (1.98°C. up to a height of 11,000 ft. 2-Sea level temperature is assumed to be 15°C 3-Sea level static pressure is assumed to be 1.225 kg/m³ 4-Sea level density is assumed to be 1013.25 hPa
explanation:
2 only

Explanation:

  1. False – The temperature lapse rate is 1.98°C per 1,000 ft (not exactly 2°C), but only up to 36,090 ft (11 km) in the troposphere.
  2. True – The sea level temperature in the ICAO Standard Atmosphere is 15°C.
  3. False – The sea level density is 1.225 kg/m³, not the static pressure.
  4. False – The sea level pressure is 1013.25 hPa, but this is not the density.
subject: Technical

question: A moving mass of air possesses kinetic energy. An object placed in the path of such a moving mass of air will be subject to which of the following:
explanation:
• Static pressure is the pressure exerted by still air or the ambient atmospheric pressure surrounding the object.
  • Dynamic pressure is the pressure exerted due to the movement of air, calculated as q = ½ ρV² (where ρ = air density, V = velocity).
  • An object placed in the path of moving air experiences both static and dynamic pressure as the airflow interacts with its surface.
subject: Technical

question: Dynamic pressure is:

choices.choice: The total pressure at a point where a moving airflow is brought completely to rest.
The amount by which the pressure rises at a point where a moving airflow is brought completely to rest.
The pressure due to the mass of air pressing down on the air beneath
The pressure change caused by heating when a moving airflow is brought completely to rest.

explanation:
“The amount by which the pressure rises at a point where a moving airflow is brought completely to rest.”

Explanation:

  • Dynamic pressure (q = ½ ρV²) represents the additional pressure exerted due to the motion of the airflow.
  • When airflow is brought to rest (stagnation point), the dynamic pressure converts into an increase in pressure.
  • This pressure rise is the difference between total pressure (stagnation pressure) and static pressure.
subject: Technical

question: Dynamic pressure is equal to:

choices.choice: Half the density times the indicated airspeed squared
Half the true airspeed times the density squared
Half the density times the true airspeed squared

explanation:
dynamic pressure (q) is given by the formula:
q = ½ ρ v²

where:

  • ρ = air density (kg/m³)
  • v = true airspeed (m/s)

this equation shows that dynamic pressure is directly proportional to air density and the square of the true airspeed.
subject: Technical

question: A tube facing into an airflow will experience a pressure in the tube equal to:

choices.choice: The difference between total pressure and static pressure

explanation:
• a tube facing into an airflow (like a pitot tube) measures total pressure.
  • total pressure (p₀) = static pressure (p) + dynamic pressure (q).
  • dynamic pressure is given by q = ½ ρ v².

thus, the pressure inside the tube is the sum of static and dynamic pressure.
subject: Technical

question: A static pressure vent must be positioned:

choices.choice: On a part of the aircraft structure where the airflow is undisturbed, in a surface at right angles to the airflow direction.
On a part of the structure where the airflow is undisturbed, in a surface parallel to the airflow direction.
At the point on the surface where the airflow reaches the highest speed

explanation: Dynamic pressure is measured using a pitot-static system, which provides Indicated Airspeed (IAS). A pitot tube, open at the forward end, measures Pitot pressure (Dynamic + Static pressure). A separate static vent, located parallel to the airflow, senses static pressure. By feeding pitot pressure to one side of a diaphragm and static pressure to the other, the static components cancel, leaving only dynamic pressure to influence diaphragm movement. The airspeed indicator, calibrated for ISA sea level (1.225 kg/m³), displays the square root of dynamic pressure in knots or mph, ensuring IAS reflects dynamic pressure variations.
subject: Technical

question: The inputs to an Airspeed Indicator are from:

choices.choice: A pilot and a static source

explanation: The Airspeed Indicator (ASI) operates using inputs from a pitot tube (which measures pitot pressure = dynamic + static pressure) and a static port (which measures static pressure). The difference between these pressures determines the Indicated Airspeed (IAS).
subject: Technical

question: The deflection of the pointer of the Air Speed Indicator is proportional to:

choices.choice: The difference between static and dynamic pressure

explanation: The Airspeed Indicator (ASI) operates by measuring the difference between pitot pressure (static + dynamic) and static pressure. Since the static components cancel out, the deflection of the pointer is proportional to dynamic pressure (½ ρV²), which determines the Indicated Airspeed (IAS).
subject: Technical

question: Calibration of the Air Speed Indicator is based upon the density:

choices.choice: At the altitude at which the aircraft is flying.
At sea level ICAO International Standard Atmosphere temperature
At sea level ICAO International Standard Atmosphere +15°C temperature

explanation: The Airspeed Indicator (ASI) is calibrated based on standard sea level density (1.225 kg/m³) under ISA conditions. Since air density decreases with altitude and temperature variations, the Indicated Airspeed (IAS) will generally differ from the True Airspeed (TAS) unless the aircraft is flying at standard sea level conditions (which is rare in actual operations).
subject: Technical

question: When considering the relationship between different types of air speed: 1-True Air Speed (TAS) is read directly from the Air Speed Indicator. 2-Equivalent Air Speed is Indicated Air Speed corrected for position error 3-Indicated Air Speed is not a speed at all,i’s a pressure 4- True Air Speed is the Speed of the aircraft through the air. Which of the above statements are true:
explanation:
“3 and 4.”

Explanation:

  • Statement 1 (False): True Airspeed (TAS) is not read directly from the Airspeed Indicator; it must be calculated using IAS, altitude, and temperature corrections.
  • Statement 2 (False): Equivalent Airspeed (EAS) is Calibrated Airspeed (CAS) corrected for compressibility error, not just position error.
  • Statement 3 (True): Indicated Airspeed (IAS) is derived from dynamic pressure and is not a direct measure of speed.
  • Statement 4 (True): True Airspeed (TAS) is the actual speed of the aircraft through the air mass.
subject: Technical

question: When considering the relationship between different types of air speed: 1-Calibrated AirSpeed is Indicated Airspeed corrected for position error 2-Equivalent Air Speed is Indicated Air Speed corrected for position error and compressibility 3-Position error, which causes false Indicated Airspeed readings, is due to variations in the pressures sensed at the pitot and static ports. 4-The Air Speed Indicator is calibrated to read True Air Speed when the ambient density is that of the ICAO International Standard Atmosphere at sea level. The combination of correct statements is:

choices.choice: Non of the statements are correct

explanation:
“1, 2, 3, and 4.”

Explanation:

  • Statement 1 (True): Calibrated Airspeed (CAS) is Indicated Airspeed (IAS) corrected for position error, which arises due to disturbances in pitot and static pressure sensing.
  • Statement 2 (True): Equivalent Airspeed (EAS) is CAS corrected for compressibility error, which becomes significant at high speeds.
  • Statement 3 (True): Position error occurs due to variations in the pressures sensed at the pitot and static ports, causing inaccurate IAS readings.
  • Statement 4 (True): The Airspeed Indicator (ASI) is calibrated for ISA sea level density (1.225 kg/m³), meaning it will only read True Airspeed (TAS) if the ambient air density matches this standard.
subject: Technical

question: The speed of sound:

choices.choice: Is dependent upon the True Air Speed and the Mach number of the aircraft.
Is inversely proportional to the absolute temperature.
Is proportional to the square root of the absolute temperature of the air
Is directly proportional to the True Air Speed of the aircraft

explanation: The Speed of Sound: (a) Sound is ‘weak’ pressure waves which propagate spherically through the atmosphere from their source. The speed at which pressure waves propagate is proportional to the square root of the absolute temperature of the air. The lower the temperature, the lower the speed of propagation. On a ‘standard’ day at sea level, the speed of sound is approximately 340 m/s (660 kt TAS).
subject: Technical

question: Mach number is:

choices.choice: The aircraft True Air Speed divided by the local speed of sound
The speed of sound in the ambient conditions in which the aircraft is flying
The True Air Speed of the aircraft at which the relative airflow somewhere on the aircraft first reaches the local speed of sound
The Indicated Air Speed divided by the local speed of sound sea level

explanation:
• Mach Number (M) is defined as the ratio of True Airspeed (TAS) to the local speed of sound (a).
  • Formula: M = TAS / a
  • The local speed of sound depends on temperature and decreases with altitude.
  • This definition helps determine compressibility effects and shock wave formation at high speeds.
subject: Technical

question: An aircraft’s critical Mach number is;

choices.choice: The speed of the airflow when the aircraft first becomes supersonic
The Speed of the aircraft when the airflow somewhere reaches the speed of sound
The Indicated Airspeed when the aircraft first becomes supersonic
The aircraft's Mach number when airflow over it first reaches the local speed of sound

explanation: Critical Mach Number (MCRIT): The critical Mach number is the Mach number of the aircraft when the speed of the airflow over some part of the aircraft (usually the point of maximum thickness on the aerofoil) first reaches the speed of sound.
subject: Technical
